ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Got a better understanding of grammar, something heritage learners dont really formally study. Also learned some more vocab, mostly formal words that the dialect and fusha dont share. I feel like I learned so much in just one semester.
This course expanded our already existing Arabic knowledge into the formal Arabic.
Fusha Arabic. Didn't realize that most of my Arabic was just dialect, this class helped me differentiate between the two.
Speaking and reading skills in Arabic

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought this class was very well put together and engaging.
Strengths: good environment; caring and involved professor; homework and exams are straightforward. Weaknesses: cannot think of one.
Very engaging, nice class size, varied activities in the course. I think having more conversation-based activities in Arabic would be great to practice speaking skills.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to Arabic speakers who are looking to improve on their skills. The professor is very kind and good at teaching.

YES! If you are a heritage speaker, definitely take Arabic. You will learn a lot more than just the dialect you use to talk to family back home. There are not many people in the class so if you have questions you are always free to ask. It's also nice to meet and get to know other Arabic speakers from similar cultures as you.
Yes, because it's a great environment to learn a new language in. There's less pressure on grades and more emphasis on learning the actual language.

extras.title: ARBC 122 01/ARBC 522 01 - MSA for Heritage Learners  I
